{{Infobox automobile | image = Koenigsegg CCX Genf 2018.jpg | name = Koenigsegg CCX | manufacturer = [[Koenigsegg|Koenigsegg Automotive AB]] | aka = | production = 2006–2010http://koenigsegg-registry.net/overview.shtml | model_years = 2006–2010 | assembly = [[Ängelholm]], [[Sweden]] | predecessor = [[Koenigsegg CCR]] | successor = [[Koenigsegg Agera]] | class = [[Sports car]] ([[S-segment|S]]) | body_style = 2-door [[targa top]] | layout = [[Rear mid-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout|Rear mid-engine, rear-wheel-drive]] | platform = [[Koenigsegg CC]] | engine = 4.7 L [[V8 engine|V8]] ([[supercharger|twin supercharged]] gasoline/ethanol)
4.8 L V8 (twin-supercharged gasoline/ethanol) | transmission = 6-speed [[manual transmission|manual]]
6-speed [[sequential manual transmission|sequential]] | wheelbase = {{convert|2660|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|4293|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|1996|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|1120|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | ground clearance = {{convert|110|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|1456|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} | related = Koenigsegg CCGT
Koenigsegg CCXR | designer = [[Christian von Koenigsegg]]
David Crafoord{{cite web|url=http://theitalianjunkyard.blogspot.se/2011/03/sweden-aint-that-cold-christian-von.html|title=The Italian Junkyard: 20.1 Sweden Ain’t That Cold: Christian Von Koenigsegg gives us a quick interview on how he made his dream come true|work=theitalianjunkyard.blogspot.se}}
[[Sven-Harry Åkesson]]{{cite web |url=https://www.elva.com/news/20140208-svenharry.php |title=Sven-Harry Åkesson |website=elva.com |language=english |accessdate=2018-01-18}} }} The '''Koenigsegg CCX''' is a [[Mid-engine design|mid-engined]] [[sports car]] manufactured by Swedish automotive manufacturer [[Koenigsegg|Koenigsegg Automotive AB]]. The project began with the aim of making a global car, designed and engineered to comply with global safety and environment regulations, particularly to enter the [[Passenger vehicles in the United States|United States car market]]. To sell cars in the US many alterations were made to the design of the CCR; the previously used [[Ford Modular engine]] was replaced by an in-house developed Koenigsegg engine designed to run on 91 [[octane rating|octane]] fuel, readily available in the United States, and to meet the [[California]]n emission standards.{{cite web|url=http://www.autoweek.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20061030/FREE/61027006|title=2006 Koenigsegg CCX|publisher=[[Autoweek]]|accessdate=2007-09-06|last=Vaughn|first=Mark|date=2006-10-30}} The name ''CCX'' is an [[abbreviation]] for ''Competition Coupé X,'' the X commemorating the 10th anniversary (X being the [[Roman numeral]] for ten) of the completion and test drive of the first [[Koenigsegg CC|CC]] prototype in 1996.{{cite web|url=http://www.koenigsegg.com/thecars/ccx.asp |title=The new CCX |publisher=[[Koenigsegg]] |accessdate=2007-08-31 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811013759/http://www.koenigsegg.com/thecars/ccx.asp |archivedate=2007-08-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Overview== The CCX was unveiled at the [[Geneva Motor Show#2006|2006 Geneva Motor Show]], sporting body modifications to meet US vehicle regulations and a new in-house developed 4.7&nhas a twin turbo in the wheel it has turbo in its eahast and mason has fake jordans bsp;L twin [[supercharged]] [[V8 engine]] capable of generating a maximum power output of {{convert|806|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} at 7,000 rpm and {{convert|920|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} of torque at 5,500 rpm while running on 91 [[octane rating|octane]] gasoline. ===Powertrain=== [[File:Koenigsegg CCX engine (Motorshow Geneva 2006).jpg|thumb|right|200px|The engine of a Koenigsegg CCX at the 2006 [[Geneva Motor Show]]]] The new engine is of all aluminium construction, made out of 356 aluminium with a [[Aluminium alloy#Temper designation|T7]] heat treatment to further enhance block integrity and cylinder bore chill during casting. Specifically created and casted for Koenigsegg by Grainger & Worrall, a casting specialist with [[Formula One|F1]] experience in drivetrain components, the engine was built, assembled and tested at their Ängelholm production plant. The engine is lubricated with a [[dry sump]] system with a separate oil pump and the pistons are cooled by means of an internal cooler that sprays oil onto them in order to run high cylinder pressure with 91 octane fuel {{cite web|url=http://www.koenigsegg.com/thecars/ccx.asp?ccx=2 |title=CCX Specifications |accessdate=2012-06-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811013612/http://www.koenigsegg.com/thecars/ccx.asp?ccx=2 |archivedate=August 11, 2007 }} making it capable of {{convert|14|mpgus|abbr=on}} in combined cycle and {{convert|18|mpgus|abbr=on}} in highway travel.{{cite web |url=http://www.koenigsegg.com/models.php?model_submenu=specs&img=1 |title=Official website of the Swedish super sports car manufacuturer |publisher=Koenigsegg |date= |accessdate=2010-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213160028/http://www.koenigsegg.com/models.php?model_submenu=specs&img=1 |archivedate=2010-02-13 |df= }} Available transmissions are a CIMA 6-speed manual and a 6-speed [[sequential manual transmission]]. Power is fed to the wheels through a torque-sensitive [[limited slip differential]]. ===Body=== [[File:Koenigsegg CCX, GIMS 2018, Le Grand-Saconnex (1X7A1713).jpg|thumb|Rear view of the CCX]] The chassis is made from [[carbon fibre reinforced plastic|carbon fibre]] reinforced with kevlar and aluminium honeycomb like the previous models. While the body keeps the [[targa top]] body style and the '''dihedral synchro-helix actuation''' doors,{{cite web|url=http://www.koenigsegg.com/thecars/design.asp?design=4 |title=The Doors |publisher=[[Koenigsegg]] |accessdate=2007-09-05 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807220358/http://www.koenigsegg.com/thecars/design.asp?design=4 |archivedate=2007-08-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }} it is completely reworked. There is a new front bumper design, enhanced brake cooling, fog lamps, US patented head lamps, a new fresh air intake on the bonnet that acts as ram air booster, air intakes behind the front wheels to enhance airflow and a glass window over the engine. [[File:CCX wheel.jpg|thumb|200px|The standard [[magnesium alloy wheel|magnesium-alloy]] rear wheel of a CCX]] The CCX has frontal area of {{convert|2894|sqin|m2|abbr=on}} and a {{Cd|long=yes|link=car|0.30}}., with a CdA of {{convert|0.56|m2|sqft|abbr=on}}. It also has a flat underside with [[venturi effect|venturi tunnels]] at the rear and an optional rear [[spoiler (automotive)|spoiler]] to improve downforce. At {{convert|200|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} there is {{convert|60|kg|abbr=on}} of [[downforce]] over the front axle and {{convert|65|kg|abbr=on}} over the rear.{{cite web| url=http://www.pistonheads.com/roadtests/KoenigseggCCX.htm|title=Koenigsegg CCX|publisher=Piston Heads|date=2006-08-17|first=Ian|last=Kuah|accessdate=2007-09-07}} The car is {{convert|88|mm|in|abbr=on}} longer to comply with the US rear impact regulations and to free space around the rear muffler. On the interior, there is {{convert|51|mm|in|abbr=on}} of extra headroom as well as specifically designed [[Sparco]] carbon fibre seats.{{cite web|url=http://www.koenigsegg.com.au/23-koenigsegg-ccx-press-release.htm|title=Koenigsegg CCX Press Release| accessdate=2012-06-22}} ===Wheels and brakes=== First in the industry carbon fibre wheels are optional equipment, {{convert|3|kg|lb}} lighter than the standard forged alloy ''telephone-dial'' wheels,{{cite web|url=http://www.koenigsegg.com/thecars/ccx.asp?ccx=2 |title=Design Elements |publisher=[[Koenigsegg]] |accessdate=2007-09-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811013612/http://www.koenigsegg.com/thecars/ccx.asp?ccx=2 |archivedate=2007-08-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }} both using center locking nuts. Diameter is 19 inches at the front and 20 inches at the rear equipped with 255/35 Y19 front, 335/30 Y20 rear Michelin Pilot Sport 2 tires, 8 piston caliper [[Disc brake#Ceramic composites|carbon ceramic brakes]] measuring {{convert|380|mm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter at the front and 6 piston caliper {{convert|362|mm|in|abbr=on}} at the rear are optional, saving another {{convert|2|kg|lb}} of unsprung weight. ==Variants== ===CCXR=== [[File:CCXR in London.jpg|thumb|right|Rear view of the light blue [[Al-Thani]] family CCXR in [[London]]]] {{Listen|filename=Koenigsegg CCX-R.ogg|title=Koenigsegg CCX-R|description=Koenigsegg CCX-R at Goodwood Festival of Speed 2009}} The '''CCXR''' is a more "environment friendly" version of the CCX, powered by the same engine, but converted to use E85 and E100 [[ethanol fuel]], as well as standard 98 octane petrol.{{Cite news|last=Grunet|first=Peter|title=Herbal Essence|newspaper=[[Top Gear Magazine]]|pages=138–142|date=2007-06-01}} The CCXR required modified [[fuel injector]]s, upgraded fuel lines and piston rings, and a higher boost setting on the superchargers. In standard form, bodywork of the CCXR features heavily optimized aerodynamics, along with optional diffusers to enhance airflow, including an optional front [[Diffuser (automotive)#splitters|splitter]] with an aerodynamic [[nolder]].{{cite web | title = CCXR Koenigsegg | publisher = Koenigsegg.com | author = | date = | quote = |url = https://www.koenigsegg.com/ccxr/}}{{cite web|url=http://www.carmagazine.co.uk/Green-Cars/Search-Results/Green-First-Pictures/Koenigsegg-CCXR/?&R=EPI-3621|title=A green Koenigsegg? Surely some mistake?|publisher=Car Magazine|accessdate=2007-09-05|date=2007-06-03|last=Whitworth|first=Ben}} When run on ethanol, the power increases to {{convert|1018|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} at 7000 rpm and {{convert|1060|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} of torque at 5600 rpm. This is a direct result of the cooling properties of [[ethanol]] in the engine's combustion chambers along with the added boost, made possible by ethanol's higher [[octane rating]] when compared to gasoline.{{cite web|url=http://www.koenigsegg.com/geneva2007/index.asp?menu=4 |title=CCXR Technical Specifications |publisher=[[Koenigsegg]] |accessdate=2007-09-05 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025011508/http://www.koenigsegg.com/geneva2007/index.asp?menu=4 |archivedate=2007-10-25 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Due to the lower specific energy content of ethanol, the CCXR burns slightly more fuel than the CCX with a combined fuel consumption of {{convert|22|L/100 km|abbr=on}} under the EU cycle. In March 2009 the CCXR was chosen by [[Forbes]] as one of the ten most beautiful cars in history.{{cite web | last = Elliott | first = Hannah | title = World's Most Beautiful Cars | work = [[Forbes]] | date = March 26, 2009 | url = https://www.forbes.com/2009/03/26/most-beautiful-cars-lifestyle-vehicles-collector-cars_slide_7.html?thisSpeed=15000}} ===Edition=== [[File:Koenigsegg CCXR Edition (1 von 2).jpg|right|thumbnail|CCXR Edition at the 2008 Geneva Motor Show.]] At the 2008 [[Geneva Motor Show]] Koenigsegg presented two special edition models, the CCX Edition and the CCXR Edition, both fitted with a remapped, 4.8 L twin-supercharged [[V8 engine|V8]] engine and limited to 2 and 4 units respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.carsuk.net/exclusive-koenigsegg-cuts-production-numbers-on-the-ccx-ccxr-edition/ |title=Exclusive: Koenigsegg cuts production numbers on the CCX & CCXR Edition | Cars UK | UK Car News |publisher=Cars UK |date=2009-03-19 |accessdate=2009-04-28}} The modifications to the engine increase the power of the CCX Edition to {{convert|888|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} on normal gasoline and {{convert|940|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} of torque while the CCXR Edition ratings remained unchanged over the CCXR. Later, Koenigsegg also built 2 CCXR Special Edition cars which when compared to the old CCXR Edition had updated aerodynamics and an F1 Paddleshift gearbox. The Edition models are more track oriented compared to the standard models, being equipped with stiffer springs and anti-roll bars, new dampers and a lowered chassis, a bare carbon body, unique 11 spoke aluminium wheels with a large adjustable '''twin-deck''' rear wing, and a larger front splitter and side skirts, all of which make the car capable of producing {{convert|350|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} of downforce at {{convert|250|kph|mph|0|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.koenigsegg.com/models/ccxr-edition/|title=CCXR Edition specifications|accessdate=2012-05-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.koenigsegg.com/models/ccx-edition/|title=CCX Edition specifications|accessdate=2012-05-24}} The interior is also reworked and features; colour matched leather carpets, Koenigsegg Edition side step plates, Edition chronograph instrument cluster, and features a special version of the Koenigsegg Chronocluster including a redesigned centre console. All other extra equipment for the Koenigsegg CCX and CCXR Edition comes as standard which include optional carbon fibre wheels, a rearview camera, Satnav or Bluetooth, amplifiers, and a complete Inconell exhaust system. ===CCXR Trevita=== [[File:Koenigsegg CCXR SE and CCXR Trevita (19842074056).jpg|Koenigsegg CCXR SE and CCXR Trevita|thumb|220px]] The CCXR '''''Trevita''''' is a limited edition of the Koenigsegg CCXR featuring a diamond weave carbon fibre finish. ''Trevita'' is an abbreviation in Swedish and translates into "three whites". {{cite web | last = Press Release | first = Koenigsegg | title = The Koenigsegg Trevita - The Shimmering Diamond | date = September 9, 2009 | url = http://www.koenigsegg.com/news.php}} The Koenigsegg Proprietary Diamond Weave, fully developed by Koenigsegg, is a new and unique method to manufacture the carbon fibre used for the CCXR Trevita. By utilising this new and unique method, Koenigsegg managed to coat the fibres with a diamond finish. The fibre treatment is conducted carefully in small quantities, prior to further processing the pre-production material.{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/sep/18/koenigseggs-trevita-is-unique/|title=Koenigsegg's Trevita is unique| publisher=[[The Washington Times]]|date=2009-09-18|accessdate=2009-10-12}} Initially, three CCXR Trevitas were planned to be produced, however, because of the complexity to make the special diamond weave carbon-fibre, only 2 were ever made, making it one of the rarest vehicles manufactured by Koenigsegg. Both cars featured the Koenigsegg Shimmering Diamond Weave bodywork, '''twin-deck''' carbon fibre rear wing, [[inconel]] exhaust system, carbon ceramic brakes with ABS, airbags, F1 paddle-shift gearbox, chrono instrument cluster, infotainment system, tire monitoring system and a hydraulic lifting system.{{cite web |url=http://www.gtspirit.com/2009/09/10/koenigsegg-trevita/ |title=Koenigsegg Trevita |work=GTspirit.com |date=2009-09-10|accessdate=2009-10-12}} The Trevita is also one of the most expensive sports cars, costing [[United States Dollar|US$]]4.8 million. {{cite web |url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/most-expensive-cars-in-the-world/ |website=Digitaltrends.com |title=The most expensive cars in the world |date=2018-08-15 |first1=Ronan |last1=Glon |first2=Stephen |last2=Edelstein}} {{clear}} ==Specifications== {| class="wikitable collapsible" style="font-size:97%; text-align:center;" |- !Models !! CCX !! CCXR !! CCX Edition !! CCXR Edition/Trevita/Special Edition |- ! colspan=5 | Engine configuration: Twin supercharged DOHC 4-valve V8 |- | style="text-align:right;"| Displacement | colspan=2 | {{convert|4.7|L|cuin|1|abbr=on}} | colspan=3 | {{convert|4.8|L|cuin|1|abbr=on}} |- | style="text-align:right;"| Power | {{convert|806|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 7000 rpm || {{convert|1018|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 7200 rpm || {{convert|888|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 7000 rpm ||{{convert|1018|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 7000 rpm |- | style="text-align:right;"| Torque | {{convert|920|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} at 5500 rpm || {{convert|1060|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}}at 6100 rpm || {{convert|940|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}}at 5800 rpm ||{{convert|1080|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} at 5600 rpm |- ! colspan=5 | Performance (mfr estimates) |- | style="text-align:right;"| 0-{{convert|100|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} | 3.2 || 3.1 || 3.0 ||2.9 |- | style="text-align:right;"| 0-{{convert|200|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} | 9.8||8.9||9.1||8.8 |- | style="text-align:right;"| 0-{{convert|200|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}}-0 | 14.0 || 13.7|| 13.9 || 13.0 |- | style="text-align:right;"| Top speed | over {{convert|395|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} || colspan=3| over {{convert|400|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} |} ==Motorsport== [[File:White Koenigsegg CCGT Goodwood 2007.jpg|right|thumbnail|250px|Only existing CCGT at Goodwood 2007]] In order to compete in the [[FIA GT Championship]] Koenigsegg created the '''CCGT''' race car, based on the production CC model range; making its debut appearance at the 2007 [[Salon International de l'Auto|Geneva Motor Show]] and built to comply with the [[Automobile Club de l'Ouest|ACO]] and [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]] regulations for the GT1 class.{{cite web|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2007/03/02/koenigsegg-drops-a-duo-ccgt-and-1018-hp-biofuel-ccxr/|title=Autoblog: Koenigsegg drops a duo| accessdate=24 May 2012}} The CCGT's engine is based on the unit used in the Koenigsegg CCX with the superchargers removed and the capacity increased to 5.0 L to compensate for the loss of power. Due to the already lightweight construction of the road-going model it was based on, the weight was easily reduced under the minimum {{convert|1100|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}}, which means that the [[Ballast weight|Ballast]] can be placed optimally in order to meet the mandatory weight. As the car neared completion, the FIA GT1 regulations were suddenly changed, according to the altered regulations, there had to be a minimum of 350 road cars produced per year of the model that was to compete, something that Koenigsegg was unable to achieve, prohibiting the CCGT from racing.{{cite web|url=http://www.koenigsegg.com/models/ccgt/|title=Koenigsegg CCGT specifications| accessdate=24 May 2012}} {{clear}} == Production == The CCX was produced between 2006 and 2010 and the total production amounted to 49 cars (30 CCX, 9 CCXR, 6 CCX/CCXR Edition, 2 CCXR Special Edition and 2 CCXR Trevita). One of them was a CCX used for Crash tests and the other was a CCXR which is still a factory test car. Some CCX cars have later been upgraded to CCXR-specifications. {{clear}} ==Awards and recognition== * 2009 Best Performing Green Exotic, ''[[duPont Registry]]''{{cite web |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2008/10/09/dupont-registrys-11-best-of-cars-set-horsepower-price-record/ |title=duPont Registry's 11 "Best of" cars set horsepower, price records |accessdate=2008-03-20 |last=Ramsey |first=Jonathon |date=2008-10-09 |work=[[Autoblog.com|Autoblog]] |publisher=[[Weblogs, Inc.]] }} * One of the 10 Most Beautiful Cars by [[Forbes]] magazine In 2007, the CCX was the fastest car to complete [[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|Top Gear's]] [[Power Laps|Power Lap]] with a time of 1:17.6 (until it was beaten by the [[Ascari A10]] with a time of 1:17.3).{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/topgear/show/powerlaps.shtml|title=Top Gear - Power Laps|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2007-10-15}} The car originally lapped the circuit in 1:20.4, but was then fitted with an optional rear [[spoiler (automotive)|wing]] to provide [[downforce]] after [[The Stig]] spun it off the track at 130mph due to a power steering failure. The Stig purportedly recommended this modification, predicting that the car would then be the fastest ever round ''Top Gear'''s track{{cite episode|series=[[Top Gear (current format)|Top Gear]]|title=[[List of Top Gear episodes#Series 8|Season 8, Episode 1]]|airdate=2006-05-07}} - Jeremy Clarkson: "After the accident, Stig said he reckons this car would be 4 seconds faster than it was if it had a big wing on the back."'' but Koenigsegg later stated that the improvement was due to adjustments to the chassis and suspension settings and not the addition of the rear spoiler. Despite this, the Stig's spoiler-idea remained the credited reason for the improved lap time.{{cite web|author=Svensson, Gunnar|url=http://www.bilsport.se/news.php?id=36110|title=Koenigsegg får Top Gear-vinge|language=Swedish|publisher=[[Bilsport]]|date=2006-06-05|accessdate=2007-03-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070406145120/http://www.bilsport.se/news.php?id=36110|archivedate=2007-04-06|df=}} The name of the car on the lap board as "Koeniggggsenisseggsegnignigsegigisegccx2 with the Top Gear wing", reportedly because none of the Top Gear Presenters knew how to spell Koenigsegg, and also poking fun at the long and hard pronunciation of the manufacturer's name. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=35em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Koenigsegg CCX}} * [http://www.koenigsegg.com/ Official Koenigsegg site] * [http://koenigsegg-registry.net/overview.shtml Unofficial Koenigsegg Registry] {{Koenigsegg}} {{Koenigsegg road car timeline, 1990s-present}} [[Category:Koenigsegg vehicles|CCX]] [[Category:Rear mid-engine, rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Sports cars]] [[Category:2000s cars]] [[Category:Flexible-fuel vehicles]] [[Category:Grand tourer racing cars]]

The '''Kutta condition''' is a principle in steady-flow [[fluid dynamics]], especially [[aerodynamics]], that is applicable to solid bodies with sharp corners, such as the [[trailing edge]]s of [[airfoil]]s. It is named for [[Germany|German]] [[mathematician]] and aerodynamicist [[Martin Kutta]].
Kuethe and Schetzer state the Kutta condition as follows:<ref name=KS/>{{rp|§ 4.11}} :A body with a sharp trailing edge which is moving through a fluid will create about itself a [[circulation (fluid dynamics)|circulation]] of sufficient strength to hold the rear stagnation point at the trailing edge.
In fluid flow around a body with a sharp corner, the Kutta condition refers to the flow pattern in which fluid approaches the corner from both directions, meets at the corner, and then flows away from the body. None of the fluid flows around the sharp corner.
The Kutta condition is significant when using the [[Kutta–Joukowski theorem]] to calculate the lift created by an airfoil with a sharp trailing edge. The value of [[circulation (fluid dynamics)|circulation]] of the flow around the airfoil must be that value which would cause the Kutta condition to exist.
== The Kutta condition applied to airfoils ==
Applying 2-D potential flow, if an [[airfoil]] with a sharp trailing edge begins to move with a positive angle of attack through air, the two stagnation points are initially located on the underside near the leading edge and on the topside near the trailing edge, just as with the cylinder. As the air passing the underside of the airfoil reaches the trailing edge it must flow around the trailing edge and along the topside of the airfoil toward the stagnation point on the topside of the airfoil. [[Vortex]] flow occurs at the trailing edge and, because the radius of the sharp trailing edge is zero, the speed of the air around the trailing edge should be infinitely fast. Though real fluids cannot move at infinite speed, they can move very fast. The high airspeed around the trailing edge causes strong [[Viscosity|viscous]] forces to act on the air adjacent to the trailing edge of the airfoil and the result is that a strong vortex accumulates on the topside of the airfoil, near the trailing edge. As the airfoil begins to move it carries this vortex, known as the [[starting vortex]], along with it. Pioneering aerodynamicists were able to photograph starting vortices in liquids to confirm their existence.<ref>Millikan, Clark B. (1941) ''Aerodynamics of the Airplane'', Figure 1.55, [[John Wiley & Sons]]</ref><ref>Prandtl, L., and Tietjens, O.G. (1934) ''Applied Hydro- and Aero-mechanics'', Figures 42-55, McGraw-Hill </ref><ref>Massey, B.S. ''Mechanics of Fluids''. Fig 9.33, 2nd Edition</ref>
The [[vorticity]] in the starting vortex is matched by the vorticity in the bound vortex in the airfoil, in accordance with [[Kelvin's circulation theorem]].<ref name=KS>A.M. Kuethe and J.D. Schetzer (1959) ''Foundations of Aerodynamics'', 2nd edition, John Wiley & Sons {{ISBN|0-471-50952-3}}</ref>{{rp|§ 2.14}} As the vorticity in the starting vortex progressively increases the vorticity in the bound vortex also progressively increases and causes the flow over the topside of the airfoil to increase in speed. The starting vortex is soon cast off the airfoil and is left behind, spinning in the air where the airfoil left it. The stagnation point on the topside of the airfoil then moves until it reaches the trailing edge.<ref name=KS/>{{rp|§§ 6.2, 6.3}} The starting vortex eventually dissipates due to viscous forces.
As the airfoil continues on its way, there is a stagnation point at the trailing edge. The flow over the topside conforms to the upper surface of the airfoil. The flow over both the topside and the underside join up at the trailing edge and leave the airfoil travelling parallel to one another. This is known as the Kutta condition.<ref name=clancy>Clancy, L.J. ''Aerodynamics'', Sections 4.5 and 4.8</ref>{{rp|§ 4.8}}
When an airfoil is moving with a positive angle of attack, the starting vortex has been cast off and the Kutta condition has become established, there is a finite [[circulation (fluid dynamics)|circulation]] of the air around the airfoil. The airfoil is generating lift, and the magnitude of the lift is given by the [[Kutta–Joukowski theorem]].<ref name=clancy/>{{rp|§ 4.5}}
One of the consequences of the Kutta condition is that the airflow over the topside of the airfoil travels much faster than the airflow under the underside. A parcel of air which approaches the airfoil along the stagnation streamline is cleaved in two at the stagnation point, one half traveling over the topside and the other half traveling along the underside. The flow over the topside is so much faster than the flow along the underside that these two halves never meet again. They do not even re-join in the wake long after the airfoil has passed. This is sometimes known as "cleavage". There is a popular fallacy called the [[Lift (force)#False explanation based on equal transit-time|equal transit-time fallacy]] that claims the two halves rejoin at the trailing edge of the airfoil. This fallacy is in conflict with the phenomenon of cleavage that has been understood since Martin Kutta's discovery.
Whenever the speed or angle of attack of an airfoil changes there is a weak starting vortex which begins to form, either above or below the trailing edge. This weak starting vortex causes the Kutta condition to be re-established for the new speed or angle of attack. As a result, the [[circulation (fluid dynamics)|circulation]] around the airfoil changes and so too does the lift in response to the changed speed or angle of attack.<Ref>"This starting vortex formation occurs not only when a wing is first set into motion, but also when the circulation around the wing is subsequently changed for any reason whatever." Millikan, Clark B. (1941), ''Aerodynamics of the Airplane'', p.65, John Wiley & Sons, New York</ref><Ref name=clancy/>{{rp|§ 4.7-4.9}}
The Kutta condition gives some insight into why airfoils usually have sharp trailing edges, even though this is undesirable from structural and manufacturing viewpoints.
In irrotational, inviscid, incompressible flow (potential flow) over an [[airfoil]], the Kutta condition can be implemented by calculating the stream function over the airfoil surface.<ref>Farzad Mohebbi and Mathieu Sellier (2014) "On the Kutta Condition in Potential Flow over Airfoil", ''Journal of Aerodynamics'' {{doi|10.1155/2014/676912}}</ref> <ref>Farzad Mohebbi (2018) "FOILincom: A fast and robust program for solving two dimensional inviscid steady incompressible flows (potential flows) over isolated airfoils", {{doi|10.13140/RG.2.2.21727.15524}}</ref> The same Kutta condition implementation method is also used for solving two dimensional subsonic (subcritical) inviscid steady compressible flows over isolated airfoils.<ref>Farzad Mohebbi (2018) "FOILcom: A fast and robust program for solving two dimensional subsonic (subcritical) inviscid steady compressible flows over isolated airfoils", {{doi|10.13140/RG.2.2.36459.64801/1}}</ref> The viscous correction for the Kutta condition can be found in some of the recent studies.<ref> C. Xu (1998) "Kutta condition for sharp edge flows", ''Mechanics Research Communications ''{{doi|10.1016/s0093-6413(98)00054-8}}</ref>
== The Kutta condition in aerodynamics ==
The Kutta condition allows an aerodynamicist to incorporate a significant effect of [[viscosity]] while neglecting viscous effects in the underlying [[conservation of momentum]] equation. It is important in the practical calculation of [[lift (force)|lift]] on a [[wing]].
The equations of [[conservation of mass]] and [[conservation of momentum]] applied to an inviscid fluid flow, such as a [[potential flow]], around a solid body result in an infinite number of valid solutions. One way to choose the correct solution would be to apply the viscous equations, in the form of the [[Navier–Stokes equations]]. However, these normally do not result in a closed-form solution. The Kutta condition is an alternative method of incorporating some aspects of viscous effects, while neglecting others, such as [[skin friction]] and some other [[boundary layer]] effects.
The condition can be expressed in a number of ways. One is that there cannot be an infinite change in velocity at the trailing edge. Although an [[inviscid fluid]] can have abrupt changes in velocity, in reality [[viscosity]] smooths out sharp velocity changes. If the trailing edge has a non-zero angle, the flow velocity there must be zero. At a cusped trailing edge, however, the velocity can be non-zero although it must still be identical above and below the airfoil. Another formulation is that the pressure must be continuous at the trailing edge.
The Kutta condition does not apply to unsteady flow. Experimental observations show that the [[stagnation point]] (one of two points on the surface of an airfoil where the flow speed is zero) begins on the top surface of an airfoil (assuming positive effective [[angle of attack]]) as flow accelerates from zero, and moves backwards as the flow accelerates. Once the initial transient effects have died out, the stagnation point is at the trailing edge as required by the Kutta condition.
Mathematically, the Kutta condition enforces a specific choice among the infinite allowed values of [[circulation (fluid dynamics)|circulation]].
== See also == * [[Kutta–Joukowski theorem]] * [[Horseshoe vortex]] * [[Starting vortex]]
==References==
* [[L. J. Clancy]] (1975) ''Aerodynamics'', Pitman Publishing Limited, London. {{ISBN|0-273-01120-0}} *[http://www.diam.unige.it/~irro/profilo_e.html "Flow around an airfoil" at the University of Geneva] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060504055740/http://pc.freeshell.org/notes/node21.html "Kutta condition for lifting flows" by Praveen Chandrashekar of the National Aerospace Laboratories of India] *{{cite book |author-link=John D. Anderson |last=Anderson |first=John |date=1991 |title=Fundamentals of Aerodynamics |edition=2nd |pages=260–263 |location=Toronto |publisher=McGraw-Hill |isbn=0-07-001679-8}} * A.M. Kuethe and J.D. Schetzer, ''Foundations of Aerodynamics'', John Wiley & Sons, Inc. New York (1959) {{ISBN|0-471-50952-3}} * Massey, B.S. ''Mechanics of Fluids''. Section 9.10, 2nd Edition. Van Nostrand Reinhold Co. London (1970) Library of Congress Catalog Card No. 67-25005 * C. Xu, "Kutta condition for sharp edge flows", Mechanics Research Communications 25(4):415-420 (1998). * E.L. Houghton and P.W. Carpenter, ''Aerodynamics for Engineering Students'', 5th edition, pp. 160-162, Butterworth-Heinemann, An imprint of Elsevier Science, Jordan Hill, Oxford (2003) {{ISBN|0-7506-5111-3}}

[[File:2013 IAA BMW i3 Honeycomb structure.jpg|thumb|right|Lightweight materials such as [[carbon fiber]] are increasingly being used in cars and trucks to decrease weight while preserving strength, as shown here in this car bumper, as an example of ''Lightweighting''.]] '''Lightweighting''' is a concept in the [[auto industry]] about building cars and trucks that are less heavy as a way to achieve better [[fuel efficiency]] and handling.<ref name=twsNYT1> JIM MOTAVALLI, OCT. 11, 2012, The New York Times, [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/12/automobiles/for-lightweight-cars-a-race-among-steel-aluminum-and-carbon-fiber.html?_r=0 For Lightweight Cars, a Materials Race], Retrieved April 11, 2015, "...carmakers and the federal government are pouring resources into “lightweighting” auto platforms to meet the Corporate Average Fuel Economy, or CAFE, standards...."</ref><ref name=twsUSAToday> Chris Woodyard, USA TODAY, June 3, 2014, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/06/03/ford-fusion-lightweight/9928467/ Ford shows off lightweight car concept], Retrieved April 11, 2015, "..."Lightweighting our vehicles is incredibly important to us in terms of improving fuel economy and reducing CO2 emissions,"..."</ref> Carmakers make parts from carbon fiber, windshields from plastic, and bumpers out of aluminum foam, as ways to lessen vehicle load.<ref name=twsMercuryNews> Dee-Ann Durbin of the Associated Press, June 17, 2014, Mercury News, [http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_25981045/auto-industry-gets-serious-about-lighter-materials Auto industry gets serious about lighter materials], Retrieved April 11, 2015, "...Automakers have been experimenting for decades with lightweighting, as the practice is known, but the effort is gaining urgency with the adoption of tougher gas mileage standards. ..."</ref> Replacing car parts with lighter materials does not lessen overall safety for drivers, according to one view, since many plastics have a high strength-to-weight ratio.<ref name=twsMercuryNews/> The search to replace car parts with lighter ones is not limited to any one type of part; according to a spokesman for [[Ford Motor Company]], engineers strive for lightweighting "anywhere we can."<ref name=twsWSJ> NEAL E. BOUDETTE and MIKE RAMSEY, Jan. 14, 2013, Wall Street Journal, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324595704578239812708897212 Detroit Sheds Pounds for Gas-Mileage Gains], Retrieved April 11, 2015, "...Today, we look at lightweighting anywhere we can," said ... of Ford...."</ref> Using lightweight materials such as [[plastics]] can mean less strain on the engine and better [[gas mileage]] as well as improved handling.<ref name=twsChicagoTribune> May 2, 2013, Chicago Tribune, [http://www.chicagotribune.com/bp/chi-branded-aranet-automotive-improving-automobile-fuel-efficiency-with-plastics-story.html Improving automobile fuel efficiency - with plastics], Retrieved April 11, 2015, "...Due to their positive strength-to-weight ratio, plastics make up an astonishing 50 percent of today’s cars by volume, but only 10 percent by weight. This “lightweighting” results in less strain on the engine and improved gas mileage...."</ref> One material sometimes used to reduce weight is [[carbon fiber]].<ref name=twsWPost> Daniel C. Esty, March 4, 2007, Washington Post, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/02/AR2007030202044.html When Being Green Puts You in the Black], Retrieved April 11, 2015, "...Toyota reported record profits last year because it put these issues at the center of its design strategy, which includes hybrid engines, "lightweighting" of its vehicles through the use of carbon fiber and other advanced materials, .."</ref> The auto industry has used the term for many years, as the effort to keep making cars lighter is ongoing.<ref name=twsUSAToday/>
Another common material used for lightweighting is aluminum. Incorporating aluminum has grown continuously to not only meet [[Corporate average fuel economy|CAFE]] standards, but to also improve automotive performance. A vehicle with lower weight has better acceleration, braking and handling. In addition, lighter vehicles can tow and haul larger loads because the engine is not carrying unnecessary weight. Even though aluminum is light, it does not sacrifice strength: aluminum body structure is equal in strength to steel and can absorb twice as much crash-induced energy.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Marin|first1=Andy|title=Vacuum Impregnation Enables Lightweight Material Use|url=https://lightweightingworld.com/vacuum-impregnation-enables-lightweight-material-use/|website=Light Weighting World|publisher=Light Weighting World magazine}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:A_letter_from_Tibet_Governor_to_a_Nepali_official.png|thumb|200px|A letter from Tibetan Governor to a Nepalese official written on lokta paper]]
'''''Lokta paper''''' is a wildcrafted, handmade artisan paper indigenous to [[Nepal]].
==Overview== Nepalese handmade lokta paper is made from the fibrous inner bark of high elevation [[evergreen]] [[shrubs]] primarily from two species of [[Daphne (plant)|''Daphne'' (plant)]] (Greek: meaning "Laurel"): ''[[Daphne bholua]]'' and ''[[Daphne papyracea]]'', known collectively and vernacularly as lokta bushes.<ref name="himalayantimes2"/>
Lokta bushes proliferate in open clusters or colonies on the southern slopes of Nepal's [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] forests between 1,600 and 4,000 m (c.5,250–13,000 ft).<ref name="positivedeviance"/>
Historically the handcrafting of lokta paper occurred in the rural areas of Nepal, most notably in the [[Baglung District]]. Today raw lokta paper is produced in more than 22 districts in Nepal, but finished lokta paper products are produced only in Kathmandu Valley and Janakpur.<ref name="HimalayanTimes"/>
Lokta paper's durability and resistance to tearing, humidity, insects and mildew have traditionally made lokta paper the preferred choice for the recording of official government records (see photo on right) and sacred religious texts.<ref name="positivedeviance"/> [[File:Lokta nepali paper menu.JPG|200px|thumb|A menu of a typical Nepali restaurant made using Lokta Paper, also known as Nepali paper. It is a popular trend with Nepali restaurants using this paper for their restaurant menu.]]
==History of lokta paper making==
The earliest surviving lokta paper document appears in Nepal's National Archives in Kathmandu in the form of the sacred Buddhist text, the Karanya Buha Sutra. The Karanya Buha Sutra was written in Lichchhavi script and block printed on lokta paper and is estimated to be between 1,000 and 1,900 years old.<ref name="forestrynepal"/>
With the introduction of paper craft imports from Tibet in the 1930s, the production of handmade lokta paper began to decline. By the 1960s competition from commercially mass-produced paper from India placed the Nepalese handmade paper industry in a state of terminal decline with only a few families in Baglung and neighboring Parbat District retaining the traditional knowledge of handmade lokta paper production.<ref name="positivedeviance"/>
In the 1970s interest in rejuvenating lokta craft paper making occurred as the tourism industry in Nepal began to grow.<ref name="geoturistica"/> Moreover, an effective conservation program was started in 1970 for the development of national parks and wildlife reserves in Nepal to provide raw materials for the development of forest based industries such as the production of lokta paper.<ref name="biodiversity"/>
In the 1980s the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the Agricultural Development Bank of Nepal/Small Farmer Development Program (ADBN/SFDP) launched the CDHP (Community Development and Health Project) project to revive Nepal's indigenous paper making processes.<ref name="positivedeviance"/>
In the late 1980s and early 1990s, with the growth of the popularity of lokta paper on the rise, Nepalese social and environmental entrepreneurs sought out and developed international trading partners and the export market for handmade lokta paper was established. Today the handmade paper industry in Nepal is growing at a rate of 15% per year.<ref name="positivedeviance"/> [[File:Handmade wildcrafted lokta paper packaging.png|200px|thumb|Handmade lokta paper packaging containing another Nepalese forest product export, [[Sapindus]] (Soap Nuts)]]
Once the lokta paper is produced it can last for some millenniums (2000–3500 years).
==Paper making process== [[File:Fabrication papier lokta.jpg|left|thumb|250 px|Manufacturing of lokta paper, [[Kathmandu]]]] Lokta paper production is a forest-based industry.<ref name="positivedeviance"/> It relies as much on a ready supply of Daphne bark as it does on the skills of traditional paper makers and block printers, and on markets for end products. There are four main steps in manufacturing and marketing of lokta paper and lokta paper craft products: 1) harvesting the lokta bark 2) processing the paper pulp 3) producing craft products from the finished paper 4) marketing the final products.<ref name="positivedeviance"/>
==Social responsibility and environmental sustainability of the industry in Nepal== The Daphne shrub, a subspecies of laurel, grows wildly and covers more than million hectares of forest land in 55 districts of Nepal, of which 25 districts have an abundant supply.<ref name="ovop"/> Like the laurel plants ([[laurus nobilis]]) of Turkey and Syria, the Daphne shrub is one of the world's few underutilized species.<ref name="cropsforthefuture"/><ref name="forestprotection"/>
Lokta is a non-wood forest product (NWFP) harvested from protected areas (national parks, reserves, conservation areas) and is an important reservoir of biological resources maintained under in situ condition in the unique and diverse Himalayan ecosystems.<ref name="biodiversity"/> When harvested, the lokta bush automatically regenerates to a fully grown 4-5 meter plant with in 5–7 years.<ref name="biodiversity"/>
'''''Women's involvement''''': The poor rural women of Nepal have traditionally been the principal forest users. Current economic conditions have reinforced the local employment of women, as many men are leaving the rural villages in search of employment.<ref name="biodiversity"/><ref name="cropsforthefuture"/>
The Cottage Industry Department of Nepal reports 377 registered handmade paper production industries, out of approximately 600 units operating in the country. Of these, 175 manufacture about 30,000 metric tons of paper products each year. Yet, despite this major increase in handmade paper production in recent years, large scale lokta resources remain untapped. Handmade lokta-based craft paper products continue to offer considerable economic sustainability for poor rural Nepalese women due to their high-quality niche market potential.<ref name="cropsforthefuture"/>
==Modern uses of lokta paper crafts==
Although the traditional uses of lokta paper were largely restricted to government documents or religious texts, today lokta paper use is wide spread. Lokta paper is used for prayer flags,<ref name="forestrynepal"/> book bindings,<ref name="forestrynepal"/> restaurant menus (see photo on right), wallpaper<ref name="telegraph"/> wrapping paper to retain the potency of incense, spices and medicine,<ref name="forestrynepal"/> packaging,<ref name="loktapaperpackaging"/> origami,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://origamiusa.org/thefold/article/paper-review-18-lokta|title=Paper Review #18: Lokta {{!}} OrigamiUSA|website=origamiusa.org|access-date=2016-08-25}}</ref> [[Nathan Miller Chocolate]] bean to bar chocolate packaging,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nathanmiller.myshopify.com/ |title=Nathan Miller Chocolate|website=nathanmillerchocolate.com|access-date=2016-08-27}}</ref> and even dresses.<ref name="thehimalayantimes"/>
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name="positivedeviance">{{cite web|url=http://www.positivedeviance.org/pdf/publications_other/BIGGSNepalpaper.pdf |title=Social Responsibility in the Growing Handmade Paper Industry of Nepal |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> <ref name="himalayantimes2">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehimalayantimes.com/fullNews.php?headline=Sustainable+paper&NewsID=350729 |title=Sustainable paper |publisher=Thehimalayantimes.com |date=2012-10-12 |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> <ref name="HimalayanTimes">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehimalayantimes.com/fullNews.php |title=Brand identity eludes Lokta Paper at home |publisher=Thehimalayantimes.com |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> <ref name="forestrynepal">{{cite web|url=http://www.forestrynepal.org/images/publications/The%20case%20study%20report%20on%20Lokta.pdf |title=Case study report on Lokta Paper at home |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> <ref name="geoturistica">{{cite web|url=http://geotur.tuke.sk/pdf/2012/n01/05_Domaracka_v3_n1.pdf |title=The renovation of handmade paper mill in Košice model proposal with possibility of application in geotourism |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> <ref name="biodiversity">{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1023%2FA%3A1008900216876 |title=Forest conservation and environmental management in Nepal: a review |doi=10.1007/BF00114046 |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25 |volume=2 |journal=Biodiversity and Conservation |pages=445–464}}</ref> <ref name="telegraph">{{cite web|author=Green Property |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/greenproperty/8474422/How-to-go-green-in-style.html |title=How to go green in style |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> <ref name="thehimalayantimes">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehimalayantimes.com/fullNews.php?headline=Women%26acute%3Bs+strength+to+the+fore&NewsID=285108 |title=Women´s strength to the fore |publisher=Thehimalayantimes.com |date=2011-04-22 |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> <ref name="ovop">{{cite web|url=http://www.aec-fncci.org/userfiles/files/New%20brouchure%202012.pdf |title=one village one product profile |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> <ref name="cropsforthefuture">{{cite web|url=http://www.cropsforthefuture.org/publication/Species-brochure/Species%20brochure-Laurel%20Laurus%20nobilis.pdf |title=enabling deployment of underutilized species |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> <ref name="forestprotection">{{cite web|url=http://www.mfsc.gov.np/uploads/lawsnplans/4%20x%206%20in12_2.pdf |title=forest and soil protection ministry nepal |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> <ref name="loktapaperpackaging">{{cite web|url=http://sinfullywholesome.com/handmade_lokta_paper_packaging.html |title=Lokta Paper Packaging Wildcrafted & Handmade |publisher=Sinfullywholesome.com |date= |accessdate=2013-02-25}}</ref> }}
{{Paper}}

revision.comment: /* Orbital characteristics */ Too terse an explanation to be meaningful to someone that does not already understand the concept
revision.text:
{{Comparison satellite navigation orbits}}
A '''low Earth orbit''' ('''LEO''') is defined by Space-Track.org as an [[geocentric orbit|Earth-centered orbit]] with at least 11.25 periods per day (an [[orbital period]] of 128 minutes or less) and an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] less than 0.25.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.space-track.org/#/recent|title=Current Catalog Files|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 13, 2018|quote=LEO: Mean Motion > 11.25 & Eccentricity < 0.25}}</ref> Most of the manmade objects in space are in LEO orbits.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sampaio|first=Jarbas|last2=Wnuk|first2=Edwin|last3=Vilhena de Moraes|first3=Rodolpho|last4=Fernandes|first4=Sandro|date=2014-01-01|title=Resonant Orbital Dynamics in LEO Region: Space Debris in Focus|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/273597440_Resonant_Orbital_Dynamics_in_LEO_Region_Space_Debris_in_Focus|journal=Mathematical Problems in Engineering|volume=2014|page=Figure 1: Histogram of the mean motion of the cataloged objects.|doi=10.1155/2014/929810|via=}}</ref> A histogram of the [[mean motion]] of the cataloged objects shows that the number of objects drops significantly beyond 11.25.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hindawi.com/journals/mpe/2014/929810/fig1/|title=Resonant Orbital Dynamics in LEO Region: Space Debris in Focus : Figure 1|website=www.hindawi.com|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
There is a large variety of other sources<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/low%20earth%20orbit|title=Definition of LOW EARTH ORBIT|website=www.merriam-webster.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/ast/faq/#s1|title=Frequently Asked Questions|last=|first=|date=|website=www.faa.gov|language=en-us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-08|quote=LEO refers to orbits that are typically less than 2,400 km (1,491 mi) in altitude.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nasa.gov/directorates/heo/scan/definitions/glossary/index.html#L|title=SCaN Glossary|last=Campbell|first=Ashley|date=2015-07-10|work=NASA|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en|quote=Low Earth Orbit (LEO): A geocentric orbit with an altitude much less than the Earth's radius. Satellites in this orbit are between 80 and 2000 kilometers above the Earth's surface.}}</ref> that define LEO in terms of [[altitude]]. The altitude of an object in an [[elliptic orbit]] can vary significantly along the orbit. Even for [[circular orbit]]s, the altitude above ground can vary by as much as {{cvt|30|km|mi}} (especially for [[polar orbit]]s) due to the [[flattening|oblateness]] of [[figure of the Earth|Earth's spheroid figure]] and local [[topography]]. While definitions in terms of altitude are inherently ambiguous, most of them fall within the range specified by an orbit period of 128 minutes because, according to [[orbital period|Kepler's third law]], this corresponds to a [[semi-major and semi-minor axes|semi-major axis]] of {{cvt|8413|km|mi}}. For circular orbits, this in turn corresponds to an altitude of {{cvt|2042|km|mi}} above the mean [[Earth radius|radius of Earth]], which is consistent with some of the upper limits in the LEO definitions in terms of altitude.
The LEO region is defined by some sources as the region in space that LEO orbits occupy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unoosa.org/documents/pdf/spacelaw/sd/IADC-2002-01-IADC-Space_Debris-Guidelines-Revision1.pdf|title=IADC Space Debris Mitigation Guidelines|last=|first=|date=September 2007|website=|publisher=INTER-AGENCY SPACE DEBRIS COORDINATION COMMITTEE: Issued by Steering Group and Working Group 4|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|quote=Region A, Low Earth Orbit (or LEO) Region – spherical region that extends from the Earth’s surface up to an altitude (Z) of 2,000 km}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nasa.gov/audience/forstudents/5-8/features/nasa-knows/what-is-orbit-58.html|title=What Is an Orbit?|last=|first=|date=2015-06-01|work=NASA|access-date=2018-07-08|others=David Hitt : NASA Educational Technology Services, Alice Wesson : JPL, J.D. Harrington : HQ;, Larry Cooper : HQ;, Flint Wild : MSFC;, Ann Marie Trotta : HQ;, Diedra Williams : MSFC;|language=en|quote=LEO is the first 100 to 200 miles (161 to 322 km) of space.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Abhijit|first=Sen,|last2=Kumar|first2=Tiwari, Sanat|date=2014|title=Charging of space debris in the LEO and GEO regions|url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2014cosp...40E2964S|journal=40th COSPAR Scientific Assembly. Held 2-10 August 2014, in Moscow, Russia, Abstract id.# PEDAS.1-41-14|language=en|volume=40|pages=|quote=LEO region (100 kms [sic] to 1000 kms)|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nasa.gov/connect/ebooks/researchers_guide_space_environment_detail.html|title=A Researcher’s Guide to: Space Environmental Effects|last=Steele|first=Dylan|date=2016-05-03|work=NASA|access-date=2018-07-12|page=7|language=en|quote=the low-Earth orbit (LEO) environment, defined as 200-1,000 km above Earth’s surface}}</ref> Some [[highly elliptical orbit]]s may pass through the LEO region near their lowest altitude (or [[apsis|perigee]]) but are not in an LEO Orbit because their highest altitude (or [[apsis|apogee]]) exceeds {{cvt|2000|km|mi}}. [[sub-orbital spaceflight|Sub-orbital]] objects can also reach the LEO region but are not in an LEO orbit because they [[atmospheric entry|re-enter the atmosphere]]. The distinction between LEO orbits and the LEO region is especially important for analysis of possible collisions between objects which may not themselves be in LEO but could collide with satellites or debris in LEO orbits.
The [[International Space Station]] conducts operations in LEO. All crewed [[space station]]s to date, as well as the majority of [[satellite]]s, have been in LEO. The altitude record for [[human spaceflight]]s in LEO was [[Gemini 11]] with an apogee of {{cvt|1374.1|km|mi}}. [[Apollo 8]] was the first mission to carry humans beyond LEO on Dec 21–27, 1968. The [[Apollo program]] continued during the four-year period spanning 1968 through 1972 with [[List of Apollo astronauts#Apollo astronauts who flew to the Moon without landing|24 astronauts]] who flew lunar flights but since then there have been no [[human spaceflight]]s beyond LEO.
==Orbital characteristics== The mean orbital velocity needed to maintain a stable low Earth orbit is about 7.8 km/s, but reduces with increased orbital altitude. Calculated for circular orbit of 200 km it is 7.79 km/s and for 1500 km it is 7.12 km/s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spaceacademy.net.au/watch/track/leopars.htm|title=LEO parameters|website=www.spaceacademy.net.au|accessdate=2015-06-12}}</ref> The [[delta-v]] needed to achieve low Earth orbit starts around 9.4 km/s. [[Atmospheric drag|Atmospheric]] and [[gravity drag]] associated with launch typically adds 1.3–1.8 km/s to the launch vehicle [[delta-v]] required to reach normal LEO orbital velocity of around {{convert|7.8|km/s|km/h|0|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{Cite book|title=How Spacecraft Fly|last=Swinerd|first=Graham|publisher=Praxis Publishing|year=2008|isbn=0387765727|location=|pages=103–104}}</ref>
[[File:Orbitalaltitudes.jpg|center|700px]]
The pull of [[gravity]] in LEO is only slightly less than on the earth's surface. This is because the distance to LEO from the earth's surface is far less than the earth's radius. However, an object in orbit is, by definition, in free fall, since there is no force holding it up. As a result objects in orbit, including people, experience a sense of [[weightlessness]], even though they are not actually without weight.
Objects in LEO encounter atmospheric drag from [[gases]] in the [[thermosphere]] (approximately 80–500 km above the surface) or [[exosphere]] (approximately 500 km and up), depending on orbit height. Due to atmospheric drag, satellites do not usually orbit below 300 km. Objects in LEO orbit Earth between the denser part of the atmosphere and below the inner [[Van Allen radiation belt]].
Equatorial low Earth orbits (ELEO) are a subset of LEO. These orbits, with low inclination to the Equator, allow rapid revisit times and have the lowest [[delta-v]] requirement (i.e., fuel spent) of any orbit. Orbits with a high inclination angle to the equator are usually called [[polar orbit]]s.
Higher orbits include [[medium Earth orbit]] (MEO), sometimes called intermediate circular orbit (ICO), and further above, [[geostationary orbit]] (GEO). Orbits higher than low orbit can lead to early failure of electronic components due to intense [[radiation]] and charge accumulation.
In 2017, a very-low LEO orbit began to be seen in [[regulatory agency|regulatory]] filings. This orbit, referred to as "VLEO", requires the use of novel technologies for [[orbit raising]] because they operate in orbits that would ordinarily decay too soon to be economically useful.<ref name=pa20170303> {{cite news |last=Messier|first=Doug |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2017/03/03/spacex-launch-12000-satellites/ |title=SpaceX Wants to Launch 12,000 Satellites |work=Parabolic Arc|date=2017-03-03 |accessdate=2018-01-22 }}</ref>
==Use of LEO== [[File:Sunrise To Sunset Aboard The ISS.OGG|thumb|Roughly half an orbit of the [[International Space Station|ISS]].]]
A low Earth orbit requires the lowest amount of energy for satellite placement. It provides high bandwidth and low communication [[Latency (engineering)|latency]]. Satellites and space stations in LEO are more accessible for crew and servicing.
Since it requires less energy to place a satellite into a LEO, and a satellite there needs less powerful amplifiers for successful transmission, LEO is used for many communication applications, such as the [[Iridium Communications|Iridium phone system]]. Some [[communication satellite]]s use much higher [[geostationary orbit]]s, and move at the same angular velocity as the Earth as to appear stationary above one location on the planet.
=== Disadvantages === Satellites in LEO have a small momentary [[field of view]], only able to observe and communicate with a fraction of the Earth at a time, meaning a network (or "[[Satellite constellation|constellation]]") of satellites is required to in order to provide continuous coverage. Satellites in lower regions of LEO also suffer from fast [[orbital decay]], requiring either periodic reboosting to maintain a stable orbit, or launching replacement satellites when old ones re-enter.
===Examples=== * [[Earth observation satellite]]s and [[spy satellite]]s use LEO as they are able to see the surface of the Earth clearly by being close to it. They are also able to traverse the surface of the Earth. A majority of artificial [[satellite]]s are placed in LEO,<ref>{{Cite web|title = NASA Earth Observatory :|url = http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/OrbitsCatalog/|website = earthobservatory.nasa.gov|date = 2009-09-04|accessdate = 2015-11-28|language = en|first = Riebeek,|last = Holli}}</ref> making one complete revolution around the [[Earth]] in about 90 minutes. * The [[International Space Station]] is in a LEO about {{convert|330|km|mi|-1|abbr=on}} to {{convert|420|km|mi|-1|abbr=on}} above Earth's surface.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition26/iss_altitude.html | title=Higher Altitude Improves Station's Fuel Economy | publisher=NASA | accessdate=2013-02-12}}</ref> and needs reboosting a few times a year due to orbital decay. * [[Iridium_Communications#Iridium_satellite_constellation|Iridium satellites]] orbit at about {{convert|780|km|mi|abbr=on}}. * Lower orbits also aid [[remote sensing]] satellites because of the added detail that can be gained. Remote sensing satellites can also take advantage of [[Sun-synchronous orbit|sun-synchronous LEO orbits]] at an altitude of about {{convert|800|km|mi|-1|abbr=on}} and near polar inclination. [[Envisat]] (2002-2012) is one example of an Earth observation satellite that makes use of this particular type of LEO (at {{convert|770|km|mi|abbr=on}}). * [[Gravity Field and Steady-State Ocean Circulation Explorer|GOCE]] orbited at about {{convert|255|km|mi|abbr=on}} to measure Earth's gravity field. * [[Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment|GRACE]] were, and [[GRACE-FO]] are, orbiting at about {{convert|500|km|mi|abbr=on}} * The [[Hubble Space Telescope]] orbits at about {{convert|540|km|mi|abbr=on}} above Earth. * The Chinese [[Tiangong-2]] station orbits at about {{convert|370|km|mi|abbr=on}}.
==Space debris== The LEO environment is becoming congested with [[space debris]] because of the frequency of object launches. This has caused growing concern in recent years, since collisions at orbital velocities can easily be dangerous, and even deadly. Collisions can produce even more space debris in the process, creating a [[domino effect]], something known as [[Kessler Syndrome]]. The [[Joint Space Operations Center]], part of [[United States Strategic Command]] (formerly the United States Space Command), currently tracks more than 8,500 objects larger than 10 cm in LEO.<ref>[http://www.vandenberg.af.mil/library/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=12579 Fact Sheet: Joint Space Operations Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100203082814/http://www.vandenberg.af.mil/library/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=12579 |date=2010-02-03 }}</ref> However, a limited [[Arecibo Observatory]] study suggested there could be approximately one million objects larger than 2 millimeters,<ref>[http://www.astronomycafe.net/qadir/q1697.html archive of astronomy: space junk]</ref> which are too small to be visible from Earth-based observatories.<ref>[http://eugen.leitl.org/tt/msg04534.html ISS laser broom, project Orion] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728181940/http://eugen.leitl.org/tt/msg04534.html |date=2011-07-28 }}</ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=February 2008}} {{British Indian units of mass}} A '''masha''' is a traditional [[India]]n unit of [[mass]], now standardized as {{convert|0.97|g}}. Grain is usually taken is rice
8 grains of rice = 1 Ratti
8 Ratti = 1 Masha
12 Masha = 1 Tola
5 Tola = 1 chattank
16 chittank = 1 sair (kg)
40 sair (kg) = 1 mann (40kg)
25 Mann = 1 Ton (1000 KG)

'''Nebojsa Nakicenovic''' (also Nebojša Nakićenović) (born 1949, [[Belgrade]], (former) [[Yugoslavia]]) is an [[Energy economics|energy economist]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.at/citations?user=JobRFRAAAAAJ&hl=en |title=Nebojsa Nakicenovic - Google Scholar Citations |publisher=Scholar.google.at |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref>
He is Deputy Director General/ Deputy CEO of the [[International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis|International Institute for Applied System Analysis]] (IIASA) in [[Laxenburg]], Austria and former Full Professor of Energy Economics at the [[Vienna University of Technology]], Austria.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://derstandard.at/1363707404859/Feste-Brennstoffe-sind-gesundheitsschaedlich |title="Feste Brennstoffe sind gesundheitsschädlich" - Forschung Spezial - derStandard.at › Wissenschaft |publisher=Derstandard.at |date=2013-10-04 |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iiasa.ac.at/web/home/about/leadership/deputydirector/deputy_director.html |title=Professor Nebojsa Nakicenovic, Deputy Director General/Deputy CEO - Deputy Director General/Deputy CEO |publisher=IIASA |date=2015-06-25 |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> He is originally from [[Montenegro]] and is now citizen of Austria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nakicenovic.com/ |title=Nebojsa Nakicenovic | Candidate for Chair of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change |publisher=Nakicenovic.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref>
He holds a bachelor's degree (B.A.) in Economics, from [[Princeton University]], Princeton, [[NJ]], United States, Masters (M.A.) and Doctorate Degree (Ph.D) in Economics and Computer Science from the [[University of Vienna]], Austria, and a Doctorate Degree (Ph.D.) Honoris Causa in Engineering Sciences, from the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]], [[Moscow]], Russia. In 2018, Nakicenovic was inducted into the [[International Academy for Systems and Cybernetic Sciences]].<ref>http://iascys.org/</ref>
Nebojsa Nakicenovic has been involved in all Assessment Reports of the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change|Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)]]. In 2000, he published, together with Robert Swart, the [[Special Report on Emissions Scenarios]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.at/citations?view_op=view_citation&hl=en&user=JobRFRAAAAAJ&citation_for_view=JobRFRAAAAAJ:z_wVstp3MssC |title=Google Scholar Citations |publisher=Scholar.google.at |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/special-reports/spm/sres-en.pdf |format=PDF |title=Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change : IPCC Special Report |publisher=Ipcc.ch |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> He was the Director of the Global Energy Assessment (GEA), which was published in 2012.<ref>[http://www.globalenergyassessment.org/] {{dead link |date=July 2015}}</ref> He was Member of the Steering Committee of the Austrian Assessment Report On Climate Change 2014, which was published in September 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung/OTS_20140917_OTS0085/bundesminister-rupprechter-klimawandel-sachstandsbericht-zeigt-dringenden-handlungsbedarf-fuer-oesterreich-auf-anhaenge |title=Bundesminister Rupprechter: Klimawandel-Sachstandsbericht zeigt dringenden Handlungsbedarf für Österreich auf | Klima- und Energiefonds, 17.09.2014 | APA-OTS |language=de|publisher=Ots.at |date=2014-09-17 |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hw.oeaw.ac.at/Autorenbuch_engl.pdf |format=PDF |title=Austrian Assessment Report Climate Change 2014 (AAR14) |publisher=Hw.oeaw.ac.at |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iiasa.ac.at/web/home/about/news/20140916-Austria-Climate.html |title=Landmark report defines climate change in Austria - 2014 |publisher=IIASA |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref>
He is a Member of several (international) scientific advisory boards and initiatives, amongst others: the [[German Advisory Council on Global Change]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wbgu.de/en/council-members/2013-2016/prof-dr-nakicenovic/ |title=WBGU: Prof. Dr. Nakicenovic |publisher=Wbgu.de |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> Earth League,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-earth-league.org/members-bios.html |title=Members Bios |publisher=Earth League |date=2013-02-01 |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> the Steering Committee of Renewable Energy Policy Network for the 21st Century (REN21),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ren21.net/AboutREN21/SteeringCommittee.aspx |title=The Steering Committee |publisher=REN21 |date=2015-06-09 |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> the [[Global Carbon Project]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalcarbonproject.org/about/who.htm |title=Who Is Who |publisher=Globalcarbonproject.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> the UN Secretary-General's High-Level Group on [[Sustainable Energy for All|Sustainable Energy For All]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/wcm/content/site/sustainableenergyforall/home/members |title=High Level Group on Sustainable Energy - Group Members |publisher=Un.org |date=2012-03-23 |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> and the Climate Change Centre Austria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ccca.ac.at/de/ueber-ccca/der-verein-ccca/vorstand/ |title=Vorstand |publisher=Ccca.ac.at |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref>
==Editorial Membership== * ''[[Technological Forecasting and Social Change|Journal on Technological Forecasting and Social Change]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journals.elsevier.com/technological-forecasting-and-social-change/editorial-board/ |title=Technological Forecasting and Social Change Editorial Board |publisher=Journals.elsevier.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> * ''Climate Policy''<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/action/journalInformation?show=editorialBoard&journalCode=tcpo20#.VXXM4kaWUug |title=Climate Policy |issn=1469-3062 |publisher=Tandfonline.com |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> * ''[[Energy Policy (journal)|Energy Policy]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journals.elsevier.com/energy-policy/editorial-board/ |title=Energy Policy Editorial Board |publisher=Journals.elsevier.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> * ''[[Current Opinion in Environmental Sustainability]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journals.elsevier.com/current-opinion-in-environmental-sustainability/editorial-board |title=Current Opinion in Environmental Sustainability Editorial Board |publisher=Journals.elsevier.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> * ''Ecosystem Health and Sustainability''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esa.org/ehs/general-information/editorial-board/ |title=Editorial Board | Ecosystem Health and Sustainability |publisher=Esa.org |date=2015-03-17 |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> * ''[[The Scientific World Journal]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindawi.com/journals/tswj/editors/energy/ |title=The Scientific World Journal: Energy |publisher=Hindawi.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> * ''Environmental Innovation and Societal Transitions''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journals.elsevier.com/environmental-innovation-and-societal-transitions/editorial-board/ |title=Environmental Innovation and Societal Transitions Editorial Board |publisher=Journals.elsevier.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> * ''Journal of Energy Strategy Reviews''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journals.elsevier.com/energy-strategy-reviews/editorial-board/ |title=Energy Strategy Reviews Editorial Board |publisher=Journals.elsevier.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref>
